@marshman503 Unfortunately, absolutely not an option for us at a community college — but most of us make sure to go “and for more depth in this area, you want Professor ____, they are our expert in this.”

I attended an awesome Intro Psych online conference today, Intro Psych Coast-to-Coast, where I was once again reminded of the power of that class. Big thanks to @GarthNeufeld @DavidGMyers @vijisathy @camgriffi and other organizers and speakers!

This has relevance to my earlier questions about who is teaching a class. Few people in our huge field manage to stay fully current in the areas they aren’t researching or teaching regularly, and can’t be expected to manage it. That’s why teaching Intro Psych is challenging! https://t.co/efxvS9drF7

@marshman503 That is so cool! Many of us are generalists enough for Intro psych, but also specialists in something particular — just not all of us. Some people spend decades deep in the rabbit hole of a sub field and have no currency outside of it.

@bradnboujie_ A person in process of getting a doctoral degree may have plenty of expertise to teach! They would have passed the masters level already. But it’s better if it’s their specific area of interest in that field of study.
@Megan_R_C Ah, no, not like that! But a history professor who only ever focused on the ancient history suddenly teaching a class on the Cold War, when they only have a basic familiarity with the era?
@KLambPhD We are now in a situation where people are forced to “bump” others due to enrollment issues, and I can’t imagine this being good for anyone.

@alecarpism Usually they are the only one teaching that because they are the only expert in that department (like I am the only one teaching Learning in mine). But sometimes, administration may switch people last minute for unrelated reasons.

To elaborate: I’m particularly interested in how students feel about being taught by someone who is learning the specific subject as they go because it’s not “their thing” though they are in that general field.

So many people I encounter think psychology is interchangeable with “mental health.” Instead, it is a broad scientific field of study, with multiple sub fields and deep areas of interest. Psychologists study many different aspects of mind and behavior. https://t.co/rvh8zfWHZ0

@EveRosenfeldPhD @tiktok_us Just do it! You likely won’t get traction right away, so you will have time to get comfortable. However: be aware that their moderation with respect to hate speech and harassment is ridiculous.

Question for students: when you are signing up for a class, do you care who is teaching it? Does it matter to you if this instructor has specific expertise in that class topic, or only if they are “nice”? What if they are suddenly replaced?
@TitaPogi That sounds like a similar view. As professors, we tend to think that it is best for students when the classes are taught by people with the most specific expertise.
@AmoneyResists Some of them think that as long as we meet minimum qualifications to teach in psych, we can all teach any psych class regardless of our specialty area or experience.

Late night #AcademicTwitter question for people who teach in #highered: does anyone else’s administration think professors in a subject area are all interchangeable and can teach anything in that area at any time? Is this more typical of #communitycolleges? Or is it just us?
